elements.content: Two interesting hybrids based on polyoxometalates (POMs) and silver-tetrazolate subunits, H­[Ag11(pytz)6(H2O)3(P2W18O62)]·H2O (1), and H­[Ag17(pytz)12(H2O)6 (PMo12O40)2] (2) (pytz = 5-(2-pyridyl)­tetrazolate), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the periphery of the Wells–Dawson POMs contains 16 Ag-pytz subunits in compound 1, which represents the highest connection of the POMs up to now. In the crystal engineering point of view, all subunits, Ag atoms, POMs, and ligands, exhibit rich and novel coordination geometries, which facilitate the formation of the highest coordination number of the POMs. Compound 2 exhibits a complicated (6,12) connecting network with (364653)­(31843051563) topology and possesses close-packed structure due to the complementary coordination mode of PMo12 a and PMo12 b. To the best of our knowledge, this is a scarce coordination mode in one crystal. In addition, the luminescent properties and electrochemical behaviors of these compounds are discussed.

X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the periphery of the Wells-Dawson POMs contains 16 Ag-pytz subunits in compound 1, which represents the highest connection of the POMs up to now. In the crystal engineering point of view, all subunits, Ag atoms, POMs, and ligands, exhibit rich and novel coordination geometries, which facilitate the formation of the highest coordination number of the POMs. Compound 2 exhibits a complicated (6,12) connecting network with (364653)(31843051563) topology and possesses close-packed structure due to the complementary coordination mode of PMo12 a and PMo12 b. To the best of our knowledge, this is a scarce coordination mode in one crystal. In addition, the luminescent properties and electrochemical behaviors of these compounds are discussed.

elements.content: By choosing smart pytz ligand and Ag+ ion to form the TMCs, two interesting hybrid compounds based on the significant surface modification of POMs were successfully obtained. Compound 1 possesses the highest coordination number of the Wells−Dawson POMs. Compound 2 possesses the complicated 3D close-packed architecture, in which two crystallographically independent PMo12’s exhibit a complementary coordination mode.

elements.content: Explored early by Zubieta and You et al., the design and synthesis of organic–inorganic hybrid materials based on polyoxometalates (POMs) have become a significant research area over recent years for POM chemists, because of both their intriguing architectures and properties as well as their potential applications in catalysis, magnetism, electrochemistry, photochemistry, and sensitive devices. Generally, one effective approach for novel hybrid assemblies is the incorporation of functional building blocks, which can afford a synergic effect. POMs, because of their intrinsic specialties, could provide abundant coordination sites, or assemble to interesting structural motifs with brand new architectures. Hence, the introduction of POMs as inorganic building blocks brews an appealing route to design novel structural motifs with improved properties, for example, improved surface area, dispersion degree, and orientation of POMs, resulting in enhanced performance such as catalytic efficiency.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Explored early by Zubieta and You et al., the design and synthesis of organic-inorganic hybrid materials based on polyoxometalates (POMs) have become a significant research area over recent years for POM chemists, because of both their intriguing architectures and properties as well as their potential applications in catalysis, magnetism, electrochemistry, photochemistry, and sensitive devices. Generally, one effective approach for novel hybrid assemblies is the incorporation of functional building blocks, which can afford a synergic effect. POMs, because of their intrinsic specialties, could provide abundant coordination sites, or assemble to interesting structural motifs with brand new architectures. Hence, the introduction of POMs as inorganic building blocks brews an appealing route to design novel structural motifs with improved properties, for example, improved surface area, dispersion degree, and orientation of POMs, resulting in enhanced performance such as catalytic efficiency.

elements.content: Up to now, a large number of POM-based hybrids have successfully been assembled through POMs covalently linked with metal–organic units. However, in the face of the large number of oxygen atoms as the smart potential coordination sites, the highest covalent connecting number of POM clusters is not more than nine reported by our group. An interesting question arising from this is whether the coordination number and mode of POMs could achieve the state of high-point. On the other hand, there is a general correlation between the complexity of the structure of the material and the functionality that it displays. So study about the coordination mode of POMs is still a challengeable endeavor to broaden applications of POMs in materials science.

However, in the face of the large number of oxygen atoms as the smart potential coordination sites, the highest covalent connecting number of POM clusters is not more than nine reported by our group. An interesting question arising from this is whether the coordination number and mode of POMs could achieve the state of high-point. On the other hand, there is a general correlation between the complexity of the structure of the material and the functionality that it displays. So study about the coordination mode of POMs is still a challengeable endeavor to broaden applications of POMs in materials science.

elements.content: To achieve the state of high-point, several main considerations should be taken into account, such as the nature of metal ions, POMs, and organic ligands, including the electric charge, polarity, redox, the coordination mode and geometry, the steric hindrance, and so on. Among these factors, the ligand is crucial, which should possess the smart features, more specifically, the smaller steric hindrance, the more donor atoms, the flexible coordination sites, the good fitting of the coordination environment of metal ions, and POMs. So the 5-substituted tetrazolate (Scheme ) captures our attention, because it is a good candidate for acting as a useful organic linker for the connection of the POM units, which have been proven by Zubieta and Shen Lin. It is particularly important that the versatility of the tetrazolate molecule lies in the availability of more donor sites (nitrogen donors) and the smaller steric hindrance, which are positive aspects for realizing the complexity of the structure and the functionality of materials. Finally, POM-based extended structures incorporating silver coordination complexes are comparatively under explored. Meanwhile, the silver atom has versatile coordination properties with coordination number varying from 2 to 6, and therefore might be chosen as the bridging linker.

elements.content: On the basis of the aforementioned points, we have chosen classical Wells–Dawson/Keggin POMs, transition metal Ag, and organic ligands pytz to construct the functional POMs-based hybrids in this work. Our primary investigation shows that this is feasible, and we obtained two significant compounds, H­[Ag11(pytz)6(H2O)3(P2W18O62)]·H2O (1) and H­[Ag17(pytz)12(H2O)6(PMo12O40)2] (2). To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the highest connection of the Wells–Dawson POMs (number = 16) up to now, and compound 2 exhibits a complicated (6,12) connecting network with (364653)­(31843051563) topology and possesses close-packed structure due to the complementary coordination mode of PMo12 a and PMo12 b.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin- Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer, and on a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer (Ag). The IR spectra were obtained on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer with KBr pellet in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. The XRPD patterns were obtained with a Rigaku D/max 2500 V PC diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation, with a scanning rate of 4°/s, and 2θ ranging from 4° to 40°. The TG analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing air with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The photoluminescence analysis was carried out on an Efinburgh FLS920 fluoresecence spectrometer. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained with a CHI 660 electrochemical workstation at room temperature. Platinum gauze was used as a counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl electrode was referenced. Chemically bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPE) were used as working electrodes.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin- Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer, and on a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer (Ag). The IR spectra were obtained on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer with KBr pellet in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. The XRPD patterns were obtained with a Rigaku D/max 2500 V PC diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation, with a scanning rate of 4°/s, and 2θ ranging from 4° to 40°. The TG analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing air with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The photoluminescence analysis was carried out on an Efinburgh FLS920 fluoresecence spectrometer. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained with a CHI 660 electrochemical workstation at room temperature. Platinum gauze was used as a counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl electrode was referenced. Chemically bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPE) were used as working electrodes.

elements.content: Compounds 1- and 2-modified carbon paste electrodes (1- and 2-CPE) were fabricated as follows: 48 mg of graphite powder and 8 mg of 1 or 2 were mixed and ground together by agate mortar and pestle to achieve a uniform mixture, and then 0.6 mL of nujol was added with stirring. The homogenized mixture was packed into a glass tube with 1.2 mm inner diameter, and the tube surface was wiped with paper. Electrical contact was established with a copper rod through the back of the electrode.

Electrical contact was established with a copper rod through the back of the electrode.

elements.content: A mixture of α-K6P2W18O62·15H2O (500 mg), AgNO3 (150 mg), pytz (40 mg), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for 1 h in air. The pH was then adjusted to 1.9 with 1 M HCl, and the mixture was transferred to an 18 mL Teflon-lined reactor. After 4 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slowly cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Green block crystals of 1 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature (yield 35%, based on W). Anal. Calcd for C36H39Ag11N30O66W18P2 (6505.55): C, 6.64; H, 0.60; N, 6.46; Ag, 18.26. Found: C, 6.62; H, 0.94; N, 6.42; Ag, 18.25. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3434 (s), 1623 (m), 1426 (w), 1167 (w), 1089 (s), 1032 (w), 952 (s), 907 (m), 784 (s), 601 (w), 532 (w).

elements.content: Crystal data for compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer and a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID IP diffractometer, respectively, with Mo Kα monochromatic radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. All structures were solved by the directed methods and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms on carbon atoms were calculated theoretically. The crystal data and structure refinements of compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in , and CCDC reference numbers are 840360 for 1 and 840384 for 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Crystal data for compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer and a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID IP diffractometer, respectively, with Mo Kα monochromatic radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. All structures were solved by the directed methods and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms on carbon atoms were calculated theoretically. The crystal data and structure refinements of compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in , and CCDC reference numbers are 840360 for 1 and 840384 for 2.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 1 is a 3D framework. As shown in Figure (left), compound 1 consists of one [HP2W18O62]5– anion, 11 Ag+ ions, six pytz ligands, and four water molecules. There are four noticeable features. First, the P2W18 clusters act as 14-dentate inorganic ligands coordinating to 16 silver centers shown in Figure (right). Although the Wells–Dawson type anion has abundant oxygen atoms available to coordinate to TMCs, its connection number reported was no more than nine. So the POMs in compound 1 represent the highest coordination number up to date. Second, Ag atoms represent multiple coordination geometries. There are 11 crystallographically independent silver atoms, which exhibit five sorts of coordination geometries coexisting in the structure (Figure ): three coordinated “T-shaped” geometry of {Ag(2)­N3} by three N atoms of two pytz ligands and­{Ag(10)­N2O}­by two N atoms of two pytz ligands and one O atoms from P2W18 clusters; four coordinated “seesaw” geometry of {Ag(4)­N3O}­coordinated by three N atoms of two pytz ligands and one O atoms of P2W18 clusters and “cross” geometry of {Ag(8)­N3O} coordinated by three N atoms of three pytz ligands and one O atoms of P2W18 clusters; and the five coordinated intermediate between square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometries, {Ag­(1,6)­NO4} (τ1 = τ6 = (β – α)/60 = 0.44, the tau trigonality factor (τ), used to quantify the geometrical distortion) coordinated by N atoms of pytz ligands, two O atoms of two P2W18 clusters, and two O atoms of two water molecules, {Ag­(5,7)­N3O2} (τ5 = 0.39, τ7 = 0.21) coordinated by three N atoms of three pytz ligands and two O atoms of two P2W18 clusters, {Ag(3)­N2O3}­(τ3 = 0.38) coordinated by two N atoms of two pytz ligands, two O atoms of two P2W18 clusters, and one O atom of water molecule, {Ag(9)­N4O1}­(τ9 = 0.23) coordinated by four N atoms of three pytz ligands and one O atom of P2W18 clusters, and six coordinated “square-bipyramidal” geometry of {Ag(11)­N4O2} by four N atoms of two pytz ligands and two O atoms from P2W18 clusters. The bond distances and angles around the Ag ions are listed in . To the best of our knowledge, these unique silver ions and their different coordination modes and configurations (shown in Figure ) coexisting in one compound have not been found in the other POMs. Third, the pytz ligands, acting as both bridging linkers and chelators, exhibit six intriguing coordination mode (A-, B-, C-, D-, E-, F-type) shown in Figure and conform perfectly to our expected design. Finally, the POMs exhibit various coordination fashions, including η1-terminal-, η2-terminal-, bridging-terminal- styles, and the coexistence of the multiple coordination fashions makes the modification of the Wells–Dawson POMs by more TMCs easier. These phenomena are all in favor of the formation of the high-connectivity Wells–Dawson POMs. In summary, the coordination modes of Ag+ ions and pytz ligands, the coordination number, and the fashion of the POMs together lead to the formation of the high-connected Wells–Dawson POMs (shown in Figure ).

Results and Discussion

Structure Description of Compound 1 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 1 is a 3D framework. As shown in Figure (left), compound 1 consists of one [HP2W18O62]5- anion, 11 Ag+ ions, six pytz ligands, and four water molecules. There are four noticeable features. First, the P2W18 clusters act as 14-dentate inorganic ligands coordinating to 16 silver centers shown in Figure  (right). Although the Wells-Dawson type anion has abundant oxygen atoms available to coordinate to TMCs, its connection number reported was no more than nine. So the POMs in compound 1 represent the highest coordination number up to date. Second, Ag atoms represent multiple coordination geometries. There are 11 crystallographically independent silver atoms, which exhibit five sorts of coordination geometries coexisting in the structure (Figure ): three coordinated "T-shaped" geometry of {Ag(2)N3} by three N atoms of two pytz ligands and{Ag(10)N2O}by two N atoms of two pytz ligands and one O atoms from P2W18 clusters; four coordinated "seesaw" geometry of {Ag(4)N3O}coordinated by three N atoms of two pytz ligands and one O atoms of P2W18 clusters and "cross" geometry of {Ag(8)N3O} coordinated by three N atoms of three pytz ligands and one O atoms of P2W18 clusters; and the five coordinated intermediate between square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal geometries, {Ag(1,6)NO4} (τ1 = τ6 = (β - α)/60 = 0.44, the tau trigonality factor (τ), used to quantify the geometrical distortion) coordinated by N atoms of pytz ligands, two O atoms of two P2W18 clusters, and two O atoms of two water molecules, {Ag(5,7)N3O2} (τ5 = 0.39, τ7 = 0.21) coordinated by three N atoms of three pytz ligands and two O atoms of two P2W18 clusters, {Ag(3)N2O3}(τ3 = 0.38) coordinated by two N atoms of two pytz ligands, two O atoms of two P2W18 clusters, and one O atom of water molecule, {Ag(9)N4O1}(τ9 = 0.23) coordinated by four N atoms of three pytz ligands and one O atom of P2W18 clusters, and six coordinated "square-bipyramidal" geometry of {Ag(11)N4O2} by four N atoms of two pytz ligands and two O atoms from P2W18 clusters. The bond distances and angles around the Ag ions are listed in . To the best of our knowledge, these unique silver ions and their different coordination modes and configurations (shown in Figure ) coexisting in one compound have not been found in the other POMs. Third, the pytz ligands, acting as both bridging linkers and chelators, exhibit six intriguing coordination mode (A-, B-, C-, D-, E-, F-type) shown in Figure  and conform perfectly to our expected design. Finally, the POMs exhibit various coordination fashions, including η1-terminal-, η2-terminal-, bridging-terminal- styles, and the coexistence of the multiple coordination fashions makes the modification of the Wells-Dawson POMs by more TMCs easier. These phenomena are all in favor of the formation of the high-connectivity Wells-Dawson POMs. In summary, the coordination modes of Ag+ ions and pytz ligands, the coordination number, and the fashion of the POMs together lead to the formation of the high-connected Wells-Dawson POMs (shown in Figure ).

elements.content: In the 3D framework, Ag ions connect the POMs and pytz molecules into a 3D architecture, which can be considered as two moieties. One moiety is the 2D double layer formed by POMs and silver atoms along the ab plane shown in Figure a. In the POM/Ag layer, the POMs act as 10-dentate inorganic ligand coordinating to Ag ions; more specifically, each POMs links with eight Ag atoms (Ag1, Ag1, Ag5, Ag7, Ag11, Ag5, Ag7, Ag11) in the ac plane forming a 1D double strand shown in Figure b. Also, Ag3 and Ag6 ions bridge POMs along the b axis forming a 1D double strand shown in Figure c. The kind of link results in the formation of 2D double layer. The other is the infinite Ag/pytz chains (shown in Figure ), which is constructed by one organ-metal subunit (11 Ag ions (Ag1, Ag2, Ag3, Ag4, Ag5, Ag6, Ag7, Ag8, Ag9, Ag10, Ag11) and six pytz ligands (A-, B-, C-, D-, E-, F-type) (Figure a, plot)). These subunits are extended by the bridging Ag3 ions to form an infinite organ-metal chain. Furthermore, the infinite organ-metal chain is further constructed by the Ag9 ions to form a double strand in the mode of “hand by hand”. Finally, the two moieties are fused together by the Ag ions resulting in a 3D framework with (34663)­(38418596) topology, if we assign the POMs as the 9-connected nodes and the organ-metal subunit as the 5-connected node shown in Figure .

elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Compound 2 

Crystal structure analysis shows that compound 2 consists of 17 Ag+ ions, 12 pytz ligands, two PMo12 anions,ndent PMo12 anions (POMa and POMb), two crystallographically independent pytz ligands, and four crystallographically independent Ag cations (Ag1, Ag2, Ag3, Ag4) (shown in Figure ).

elements.content: It is worth noting that there are two crystallographically independent PMo12’s and their coordination modes are very interesting; more specifically, all six terminal oxygens of the equatorial ring of POMa (Figure a) and all six terminal oxygens of the two poles of POMb (Figure b) participate in the coordination with Ag ions, which exhibit a complementary coordination mode to all 12 terminal oxygen atoms of Keggin POM (Figure c). To the best of our knowledge, this is a scarce coordination mode in one crystal.

elements.content: The complicated 3D architecture of compound 2 can also be considered as being constructed from two motifs: the subunits A and B. Drum-like subunit A is formed by PMo12 a cluster, pytz, and silver atoms (Figure a and b). First, Ag1 exhibits distorted octahedral geometry that is completed by four nitrogen atoms from two pairs of different pytz- ligands, two terminal oxygen atoms from two PMo12 a (selected bond length and angle in ), so that six Ag1 atoms surround the equatorial ring of every PMo12 a via its six terminal oxygens forming the barrel of the drum. Second, the Ag2 and Ag3 show a similar triangular coordination environment that is completed by three nitrogen atoms of two different pytz ligands (selected bond length and angle in ) in building units A. Further, pytz links Ag2 and Ag3 alternately forming a {Ag2-ptz-Ag3-ptz-Ag2}3 closed toroidal ring shown in Figure c. The interesting part is that the closed toroidal rings cap on the upper and lower portions of the barrel of the drum forming the drumhead. So an integrated drum-like subunit A is obtained. Because of the bridging of Ag1, subunit A is extended to the 2D layer on the ab plane, in which Ag4 atoms further stabilize the 2D structure shown in Figure d and e. Subunit B is constructed only by the PMo12 b. The B acting as hexad-dentate (Figure a) ligands pillars the 2D sheets to form a 3D POM-pillared framework via Ag3 ions along the c axis (Figure b). To comprehend the structure better, the 3D structure can be rationalized as a (6,12) connecting network with (364653)­(31843051563) topology if we assign the −(POM)– (metal–organic-units) as the connectors and the subunits A and subunits B as the nodes (shown in Figure c). In this simplification, the 6-connected nodes are subunits B, and the 12-connected nodes are the subunits A. Note that the 3D framework possesses close-packed structure due to the complementary coordination mode of PMo12 a and PMo12 b.

elements.content: The XRPD patterns for 1 and 2 are presented in . The diffraction peaks of both simulated and experimental patterns match well, thus indicating that the phase purities of the compounds 1 and 2 are good. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and the experimental patterns is due to the different orientation of the crystals in the powder samples. The IR spectra of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in . For compound 1, characteristic bands at 1089, 952, 907, and 784 cm–1 are attributed to the ν­(P–Oa), ν­(W–Od), and ν­(W–Ob–W) of the {P2W18} polyanion. For compound 2, characteristic bands at 1061, 953, 872, and 802 cm–1 are attributed to the ν­(P–O), ν­(Mo–Od), ν­(Mo–Ob–Mo), and ν­(Mo–Oc–Mo) of the Keggin polyoxoanions. The characteristic absorption bands in the range of 1300–1700 cm–1 can be regarded as features of the pytz group. Additionally, to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, its thermal behavior was studied by TG-DTA (). The experiment was performed on crystalline samples under air atmosphere. For compound 1, the thermal analysis gives a total loss of 14.51% in the range of 40–622 °C, which agrees with the calculated weight loss of 14.56%: the first weight loss of 0.30% at 40–210 °C corresponds to the loss of one water molecule per formula (calc 0.27%), and the second continuous weight loss of 14.21% at 210–622 °C arises from the decomposition of coordinated water and pytz (calc 14.29%). All of the weight losses at 350 and 594 °C are followed by strong exothermic peaks in DTA curves, corresponding to the decomposition of organic molecules. For compound 2, the TGA shows one step of weight loss, and the weight loss of 25.28% (calc 25.33%) from 40 to 470 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated water molecules and pytz. All of the weight losses at 373 and ca. 440 °C are followed by strong exothermic peaks in DTA curves, corresponding to the decomposition of organic molecules. These results further confirm the formula of compounds.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD Characterization, FT-IR Spectra, and TG-DTA Analysis

The XRPD patterns for 1 and 2 are presented in . The diffraction peaks of both simulated and experimental patterns match well, thus indicating that the phase purities of the compounds 1 and 2 are good. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and the experimental patterns is due to the different orientation of the crystals in the powder samples. The IR spectra of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in . For compound 1, characteristic bands at 1089, 952, 907, and 784 cm-1 are attributed to the ν(P-Oa), ν(W-Od), and ν(W-Ob-W) of the {P2W18} polyanion. For compound 2, characteristic bands at 1061, 953, 872, and 802 cm-1 are attributed to the ν(P-O), ν(Mo-Od), ν(Mo-Ob-Mo), and ν(Mo-Oc-Mo) of the Keggin polyoxoanions. The characteristic absorption bands in the range of 1300-1700 cm-1 can be regarded as features of the pytz group. Additionally, to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, its thermal behavior was studied by TG-DTA (). The experiment was performed on crystalline samples under air atmosphere. For compound 1, the thermal analysis gives a total loss of 14.51% in the range of 40-622 °C, which agrees with the calculated weight loss of 14.56%: the first weight loss of 0.30% at 40-210 °C corresponds to the loss of one water molecule per formula (calc 0.27%), and the second continuous weight loss of 14.21% at 210-622 °C arises from the decomposition of coordinated water and pytz (calc 14.29%). All of the weight losses at 350 and 594 °C are followed by strong exothermic peaks in DTA curves, corresponding to the decomposition of organic molecules. For compound 2, the TGA shows one step of weight loss, and the weight loss of 25.28% (calc 25.33%) from 40 to 470 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated water molecules and pytz. All of the weight losses at 373 and ca. 440 °C are followed by strong exothermic peaks in DTA curves, corresponding to the decomposition of organic molecules. These results further confirm the formula of compounds.

elements.content: POMs have been exploited extensively in the electrocatalytic reductions by chemically modified electrode (CME), because of the ability to undergo reversible multielectron redox processes. However, because of the good solubility of the traditional CME with POMs, its application is limited.The three-dimensional bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) have been widely applied in electrochemistry with advantages: inexpensive, easy to handle, and easy to prepare. Herein, the electrochemical activities of 1 and 2 were investigated by using 1- and 2-CPE. In the potential range, we explored their typical cyclic voltammetric behavior of CPEs in 1 mol L–1 H2SO4 aqueous solution at different scan rates. As shown in Figure , left, in the potential range of −800 to +400 mV, three pairs of reversible redox peaks (I–I′, II–II′, III–III′) appear, and the mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pc + E pa)/2 are −107, −347, and −568 mV for 1 (scan rate: 30 mV/s), respectively, which should be ascribed to three consecutive two-electron processes of W centers. Also, an additional irreversible anodic peak (IV) should be assigned to the oxidation of Ag­(I). In the given range of −100 to +800 mV for 2-CPE, there exist three reversible redox peaks with half-wave potentials at +410 (I–I′), +256 (II–II′), and +22 (III–III′) mV for 2, respectively, showing three continuous two–electron procesess of Mo atoms. However, the oxidation peak of Ag centers is not observed in the scan range. A similar result was also observed in other polyoxometalates assembly.As compared to the reported P2W18 and PMo12 system, the slight potential shifts of the three redox peaks in 1- and 2-CPE may be related to the combination of Ag-organic subunits. Furthermore, with the scan rate increasing, the peak potentials change gradually: the cathodic peak potentials shifted to the negative direction and the corresponding anodic peak potentials to the positive direction; the peak–to–peak separation between the corresponding cathodic and anodic peaks increased, but the mean peak potentials did not change on the whole.
elements.clean_text:
Voltammetric Behavior of 1-, 2-CPE in Aqueous Electrolyte and Electrocatalytic Activity

POMs have been exploited extensively in the electrocatalytic reductions by chemically modified electrode (CME), because of the ability to undergo reversible multielectron redox processes. However, because of the good solubility of the traditional CME with POMs, its application is limited.The three-dimensional bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) have been widely applied in electrochemistry with advantages: inexpensive, easy to handle, and easy to prepare. Herein, the electrochemical activities of 1 and 2 were investigated by using 1- and 2-CPE. In the potential range, we explored their typical cyclic voltammetric behavior of CPEs in 1 mol L-1 H2SO4 aqueous solution at different scan rates. As shown in Figure , left, in the potential range of -800 to +400 mV, three pairs of reversible redox peaks (I-I', II-II', III-III') appear, and the mean peak potentials E 1/2 = (E pc + E pa)/2 are -107, -347, and -568 mV for 1 (scan rate: 30 mV/s), respectively, which should be ascribed to three consecutive two-electron processes of W centers. Also, an additional irreversible anodic peak (IV) should be assigned to the oxidation of Ag(I). In the given range of -100 to +800 mV for 2-CPE, there exist three reversible redox peaks with half-wave potentials at +410 (I-I'), +256 (II-II'), and +22 (III-III') mV for 2, respectively, showing three continuous two-electron procesess of Mo atoms. However, the oxidation peak of Ag centers is not observed in the scan range. A similar result was also observed in other polyoxometalates assembly.As compared to the reported P2W18 and PMo12 system, the slight potential shifts of the three redox peaks in 1- and 2-CPE may be related to the combination of Ag-organic subunits. Furthermore, with the scan rate increasing, the peak potentials change gradually: the cathodic peak potentials shifted to the negative direction and the corresponding anodic peak potentials to the positive direction; the peak-to-peak separation between the corresponding cathodic and anodic peaks increased, but the mean peak potentials did not change on the whole.

elements.content: As is known, POMs have been exploited extensively in electrocatalytic reductions. Herein, compounds 1 and 2 were employed to fabricate POM nanoparticle-modified electrodes to electrocatalyze the reduction of bromate. Figure shows cyclic voltammograms for the electrocatalytic reduction of bromate at 1- and 2-CPE in 1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution. It can be seen that, with the addition of bromate, the reduction peak currents increase gradually and the corresponding oxidation peak currents decrease gradually. The phenomenon suggests that bromate is reduced by the reduced species of W and Mo. The facts indicate that 1- and 2-CPE exhibit good electrocatalytic activity for the reduction of bromate.

elements.content: Recently, inorganic–organic hybrid compounds, especially comprising the d10 metal center and an aromatic-containing system, have been intensively investigated for attractive fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. In this work, the luminescence properties of compounds 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature (shown in Figure ). The intense emission peak of 1 is found at 433 nm with an excitation band at 350 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, compound 2 exhibits a strong peak at 439 nm, which may originate from the AgI–π interactions between AgI and the pytz ligand. The slight difference in their emissions is probably due to a result of the effect of metal–ligand coordination and interchromophore coupling. The result suggests that the POMs have no significant effect on the luminescence properties of compounds, and transition metal complexes are the active center for luminescence properties.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Recently, inorganic-organic hybrid compounds, especially comprising the d10 metal center and an aromatic-containing system, have been intensively investigated for attractive fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. In this work, the luminescence properties of compounds 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature (shown in Figure ). The intense emission peak of 1 is found at 433 nm with an excitation band at 350 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, compound 2 exhibits a strong peak at 439 nm, which may originate from the AgI-π interactions between AgI and the pytz ligand. The slight difference in their emissions is probably due to a result of the effect of metal-ligand coordination and interchromophore coupling. The result suggests that the POMs have no significant effect on the luminescence properties of compounds, and transition metal complexes are the active center for luminescence properties.

elements.content: By using smart Ag+ ions and pytz ligands as building elements, two hybrid compounds based on the significant surface modification of POMs were successfully obtained. Compound 1 possesses the highest coordination number and the richest coordination fashion of the Wells–Dawson POMs. Also, compound 2 possesses the complicated 3D close-packed architecture, in which two crystallographically independent PMo12’s exhibit a complementary coordination mode. The informative structures of compounds 1 and 2 indicate that the assembly of novel POM-TMCs hybrids depends on a synergic effect of polyoxoanion templates, metal ion coordination geometries, and the steric hindrance of TMCs. However, among these factors, the ligand is crucial and should possess the smart features. To some extent, compounds 1 and 2 provide good examples of reasonable design and controllable assembly of POM-based coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

By using smart Ag+ ions and pytz ligands as building elements, two hybrid compounds based on the significant surface modification of POMs were successfully obtained. Compound 1 possesses the highest coordination number and the richest coordination fashion of the Wells-Dawson POMs. Also, compound 2 possesses the complicated 3D close-packed architecture, in which two crystallographically independent PMo12's exhibit a complementary coordination mode. The informative structures of compounds 1 and 2 indicate that the assembly of novel POM-TMCs hybrids depends on a synergic effect of polyoxoanion templates, metal ion coordination geometries, and the steric hindrance of TMCs. However, among these factors, the ligand is crucial and should possess the smart features. To some extent, compounds 1 and 2 provide good examples of reasonable design and controllable assembly of POM-based coordination polymers.

A mixture of α-K6P2W18O62·15H2O (500 mg), AgNO3 (150 mg), pytz (40 mg), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for 1 h in air. The pH was then adjusted to 1.9 with 1 M HCl, and the mixture was transferred to an 18 mL Teflon-lined reactor. After 4 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slowly cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Green block crystals of 1 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature (yield 35%, based on W). Anal. Calcd for C36H39Ag11N30O66W18P2 (6505.55): C, 6.64; H, 0.60; N, 6.46; Ag, 18.26. Found: C, 6.62; H, 0.94; N, 6.42; Ag, 18.25. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3434 (s), 1623 (m), 1426 (w), 1167 (w), 1089 (s), 1032 (w), 952 (s), 907 (m), 784 (s), 601 (w), 532 (w).

A mixture of H3[PMo12O40] (300 mg), AgNO3 (150 mg), pytz (40 mg), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for 1 h in air. The pH was then adjusted to 2.5 with 1 M HCl, and the mixture was transferred to an 18 mL Teflon-lined reactor. After 4 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slowly cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Yellow block crystals of 2 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature (yield 41%, based on Mo). Anal. Calcd for C72H61Ag17Mo24N60O86P2 (7340.89): C, 11.77; H, 0.83; N, 11.44; Ag, 25.01. Found: C, 11.69; H, 1.13; N, 11.38; Ag, 25.01. For compound 2, the TGA shows one step of weight loss, and the weight loss of 25.28% (calc 25.33%) from 40 to 470 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated water molecules and pytz. All of the weight losses at 373 and ca. 440 °C are followed by strong exothermic peaks in DTA curves, corresponding to the decomposition of organic molecules. These results further confirm the formula of compounds.

Luminescent Properties

Recently, inorganic–organic hybrid compounds, especially comprising the d10 metal center and an aromatic-containing system, have been intensively investigated for attractive fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. In this work, the luminescence properties of compounds 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature (shown in Figure ). The intense emission peak of 1 is found at 433 nm with an excitation band at 350 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, compound 2 exhibits a strong peak at 439 nm, which may originate from the AgI–π interactions between AgI and the pytz ligand. The slight difference in their emissions is probably due to a result of the effect of metal–ligand coordination and interchromophore coupling. The result suggests that the POMs have no significant effect on the luminescence properties of compounds, and transition metal complexes are the active center for luminescence properties.
cln_elements.clean_text:
XRPD Characterization, FT-IR Spectra, and TG-DTA Analysis

The XRPD patterns for 1 and 2 are presented in . The diffraction peaks of both simulated and experimental patterns match well, thus indicating that the phase purities of the compounds 1 and 2 are good. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and the experimental patterns is due to the different orientation of the crystals in the powder samples. The IR spectra of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in . For compound 1, characteristic bands at 1089, 952, 907, and 784 cm-1 are attributed to the ν(P-Oa), ν(W-Od), and ν(W-Ob-W) of the {P2W18} polyanion. For compound 2, characteristic bands at 1061, 953, 872, and 802 cm-1 are attributed to the ν(P-O), ν(Mo-Od), ν(Mo-Ob-Mo), and ν(Mo-Oc-Mo) of the Keggin polyoxoanions. The characteristic absorption bands in the range of 1300-1700 cm-1 can be regarded as features of the pytz group. Additionally, to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, its thermal behavior was studied by TG-DTA (). The experiment was performed on crystalline samples under air atmosphere. For compound 1, the thermal analysis gives a total loss of 14.51% in the range of 40-622 °C, which agrees with the calculated weight loss of 14.56%: the first weight loss of 0.30% at 40-210 °C corresponds to the loss of one water molecule per formula (calc 0.27%), and the second continuous weight loss of 14.21% at 210-622 °C arises from the decomposition of coordinated water and pytz (calc 14.29%). All of the weight losses at 350 and 594 °C are followed by strong exothermic peaks in DTA curves, corresponding to the decomposition of organic molecules. For compound 2, the TGA shows one step of weight loss, and the weight loss of 25.28% (calc 25.33%) from 40 to 470 °C corresponds to the removal of coordinated water molecules and pytz. All of the weight losses at 373 and ca. 440 °C are followed by strong exothermic peaks in DTA curves, corresponding to the decomposition of organic molecules. These results further confirm the formula of compounds.

Luminescent Properties

Recently, inorganic-organic hybrid compounds, especially comprising the d10 metal center and an aromatic-containing system, have been intensively investigated for attractive fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. In this work, the luminescence properties of compounds 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature (shown in Figure ). The intense emission peak of 1 is found at 433 nm with an excitation band at 350 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, compound 2 exhibits a strong peak at 439 nm, which may originate from the AgI-π interactions between AgI and the pytz ligand. The slight difference in their emissions is probably due to a result of the effect of metal-ligand coordination and interchromophore coupling. The result suggests that the POMs have no significant effect on the luminescence properties of compounds, and transition metal complexes are the active center for luminescence properties.
